6 Minute English
speaker: Rob

text: From BBC Learning English.
Hello, welcome to 6 Minute English, I'm Rob.
And hello, I'm Neil.
Now, Neil, how do you feel about surf and turf?
speaker: surf and turf

text: Surf and turf? I love it.
What's not to love? Some lobster, a juicy steak, fries on the side.
Mmm, delicious.
Ah, you know what you've done there?
speaker: Rob

text: No, do tell.
You've got completely the wrong end of the stick.
speaker: Rob

text: I said steak, not steak. A juicy steak.
No! Wrong end of the stick
speaker: surf and turfsurfing and turfing

text: You misunderstood me.
I'm not talking about the surf and turf meal,
but the online shopping habit of surfing and surfing.
Ah, my bad.
But to be fair, this is quite a new use of this expression, isn't it?
Yes, it is.
speaker: Surf and turfcheckout

text: Now, you probably know that surfing is a verb we use
for looking at things on the internet.
Surf and turf refers to when we go to an online store,
select lots of things for our virtual shopping basket.
But when we get to the checkout,
which is the place where we pay for our shopping,
we don't actually complete the purchase.
We turf out the basket, we abandon it.
To turf something out is a frazel verb for throwing something out.
Although it's normally used about people, for example,
someone who is behaving badly might be turfed out of a club.
Indeed.
speaker: turfed out

text: Well, I'm sure I'll get turfed out of the presenters union
if I don't get to today's quiz question.
According to recent research,
which items are the most likely to be surfed and turfed?
Is it A books, B watches, or C women's knitwear?
What do you think, Neil?
speaker: turfed out

text: Uh, right, I think.
I'm almost certain it's A books.
Well, we'll find out if you're right later in the program.
speaker: Neil

text: Now, this research also revealed that approximately 40% of people
have abandoned an online shopping basket in the last year.
And it was calculated that this meant there was approximately
speaker: Neil

text: £18 billion worth of lost sales.
I have to say, I'm a bit skeptical about that figure.
I don't trust it.
We don't always intend to buy everything we put in our baskets.
It's a bit like window shopping,
and we just browse and find it convenient to put things
in our basket to think about later.
Have you ever done that?
Sure. It's a bit like browsing in a shop, isn't it
speaker: Neil

text: Except you can save items you are interested in to look at later.
You might also make a basket in one online store,
then go to another to see if you can get the same
or similar items cheaper there.
So I agree, I don't think that the figure of £18 billion
represents a total.
Some of that was never intended to be spent,
and some would have gone to other stores.
But there are other reasons we don't complete our purchases.
For some, it's finding out at the end
that there'll be a high delivery cost
or that paying is very complicated.
Yes, I agree with that. That's so annoying.
speaker: Neil

text: You spend time collecting all the things in the basket,
then find you have to create an account
or can't use your favourite payment method,
or you have to pay more to use a credit card
and you have to fill out so many details.
Sometimes you get so frustrated that you just give up.
Exactly.
And this is a subject that retail expert Claire Bailey
discussed in the BBC programme You and Yours.
She talks about retailers, which are the businesses
that sell things.
What does she say 70% of retailers hadn't done?
We found that something over 70% of the retailers
speaker: retailersout of datefell foul

text: hadn't invested in the payment process in the last two years,
so the technology is really out of date,
whereas they have potentially invested
in getting us to that page and then they fell foul.
70% of retailers hadn't invested in the payment process.
They hadn't changed the way people pay online for at least two years.
Because online technology develops so quickly,
speaker: out of dateout of date

text: that means that their systems are out of date.
Something that is out of date is too old.
It's no longer suitable.
She says that companies invest in the shopping experience
of their sites, but have ignored the checkout process.
This is where they fall foul.
This is where they make a mistake and get into trouble
and where they can lose customers.
Right, before we fall foul of the listeners,
let's have the answer to the quiz.
I asked you which items were the most commonly abandoned
at the virtual checkout?
Was it books, watches or women's knitwear?
So Neil, what did you say?
I am pretty certain it's books.
Ah, the answer was actually women's knitwear,
not books as you thought.
speaker: Neil

text: Ah well, I can't be right all the time.
speaker: Neil

text: Now, some of the time would be nice.
Anyway, let's have a look at today's vocabulary.
First, surf and turf is an expression for online shopping
without the actual shopping.
You put items in your basket, but never actually buy them.
It's also a delicious meal of seafood and red meat.
speaker: Neil

text: Not if you're a vegetarian.
Ah, good point, good point.
speaker: Neil

text: The verb to turf out means to remove someone
from a place or organization,
possibly because they've broken the rules or behaved badly.
For example, if we don't finish the program on time,
we might be turfed out of this studio.
The place where you pay for your shopping,
speaker: checkoutcheck outcheckout

text: either in a real shop or online, is the checkout.
That can be a verb as well as a noun.
You checkout at the checkout.
The businesses that sell you things are retailers,
And with hope they don't sell you things that are out of date
speaker: out of date

text: because that would mean they're past their best.
Too old to be suitable.
And finally, there was to full foul of something
or someone, which is to make a mistake
and get into trouble with someone.
And as we don't want to full foul of the next team
who need to use this studio,
it's just time for us to say goodbye
and to remind you to join it again
for six minute English next time.
And if you can't wait, you can always catch us
on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, YouTube,

where you can find lots of useful audio

That's all for now. Bye-bye.
